examples.en: Apparently this man is from a country in the East.
examples.ja: この男は、東方の国から来たらしい。

examples.en: The treasure is said to be somewhere in the lands to the east.
examples.ja: その宝は、東方の地のどこかにあるそうだ。

examples.en: I heard that cow was born in the eastern land.
examples.ja: あの牛は、東方の地の生まれだそうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>east</kanji> <kanji>direction</kanji> is <vocabulary>eastward</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the East</vocabulary>.

This word has an old-fashioned feel to it, so you may only encounter it in fiction or historical writing. Or, if you're a gamer, the 東方 Project series of games.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Tofugu won a narrow victory in a copyright infringement suit.
examples.ja: トーフグは著作権侵害の裁判で辛勝しました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>spicy</kanji> <kanji>win</kanji> is a <vocabulary>narrow victory</vocabulary>. Kind of makes sense, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our company is enjoying the benefits of cheap yen.
examples.ja: 我が社は円安の恩恵をもろに享受しているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The best thing to <kanji>receive</kanji> and <kanji>accept</kanji> into your life is <vocabulary>enjoyment</vocabulary>! Don't block it out, let it in! Be happy!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is Picasso’s masterpiece.
examples.ja: これはピカソの傑作だね。

meaning_mnemonic: Something you <kanji>make</kanji> that oozes with <kanji>greatness</kanji> is your <vocabulary>masterpiece</vocabulary>. The very <vocabulary>best work</vocabulary> you'll ever make in your entire life.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Who do you think the greatest hero in Japanese history is?
examples.ja: 日本史上、 最強の豪傑は誰だと思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you look back in history and see someone of <kanji>exceptional</kanji> <kanji>greatness</kanji>, they're probably a <vocabulary>hero</vocabulary>. Not just a normal person, but an <vocabulary>extraordinary person</vocabulary> like Hercules or Mae Jemison.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I was poor I ate weeds to stave off starvation.
examples.ja: 貧乏な時は、雑草を食べて飢えを凌いでいました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>endure</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to keep out</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: We can't say anything until we perform an autopsy.
examples.ja: 解剖をしてみないと何とも言えません。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Divide</kanji> a body and <kanji>untie</kanji> its organs to perform an <vocabulary>autopsy</vocabulary>. You have to cut it all up and untangle the parts to see why this person or animal died.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You, idiot! Look straight ahead and walk.
examples.ja: この呆け！ちゃんと前見て歩け。

examples.en: That is what a fool would say.
examples.ja: それは呆けの言うことだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone who's <kanji>shock</kanji>ed at everything all the time will seem like an <vocabulary>idiot</vocabulary>. At this point, putting your drinks in a glass shouldn't be surprising. I mean, come on. Only a <vocabulary>fool</vocabulary> lets himself be shocked by everything he sees.
reading_mnemonic: Remember when you learned 呆ける? Well just cut the る part off the end and it's exactly the same! If you can remember that, you'll remember this reading as well.

examples.en: Everyone was taken aback by the woman’s odd behavior.
examples.ja: 彼女のおかしな言動に、みんな呆気に取られていました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>energy</kanji> of being <kanji>shock</kanji>ed fills your body and leaves you <vocabulary>dumbfounded</vocabulary>. You're so <vocabulary>taken aback</vocabulary> by this surge of shock that all you can do is stand still and let the energy go through you.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. Just remember that they're the two readings you didn't learn when you learned the kanji and you should be okay.

examples.en: I was utterly amazed because the room was horribly dirty.
examples.ja: 部屋があまりに汚かったので、呆れ返ってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a combination of the word 呆れる meaning "to be amazed" and 返る meaning "to be returned." You're so amazed at something that it keeps returning to your mind. It means <vocabulary>to be utterly amazed</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 呆れる and 返る. 呆れる becomes 呆れ and you just add 返る to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

examples.en: That person is a part-time employee who used the reemployment system.
examples.ja: あの人は、再雇用制度を利用した嘱託社員なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A company <kanji>request</kanji>s <kanji>consign</kanji>ment work and you take it to become a <vocabulary>part time employee</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My company president is busy running around financing.
examples.ja: うちの社長は資金繰りに奔走しています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>bustle</kanji> and <kanji>run</kanji> around all day from being busy you end up <vocabulary>running about</vocabulary> to get them all done. You'll <vocabulary>be busy</vocabulary> getting it all done, but your <vocabulary>efforts</vocabulary> won't be in vain!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was attracted to his free and uninhibited personality.
examples.ja: あの自由奔放な性格に惹かれてしまったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Some day you'll <kanji>run</kanji> around, <kanji>release</kanji>d from the world and its troubles and you'll end up running <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary>. All your actions will be completely <vocabulary>uninhibited</vocabulary> when you aren't tied to your school or your job. It will be great!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

examples.en: Let’s assume birds have become an intermediary for infectious diseases.
examples.ja: 鳥が伝染病の媒介となると仮定しよう。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mediator</kanji> <kanji>jammed in</kanji> the middle of a group of angry people ends up becoming the <vocabulary>intermediary</vocabulary> between them. The mediator can't just ignore what's happening around them, and they have the tools to fix this.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: For some reason I feel more comfortable getting information from paper media.
examples.ja: 紙媒体で仕入れた情報の方が何故か安心するんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mediator</kanji> who works with someone who doesn't have a <kanji>body</kanji> has to use some kind of mortal <vocabulary>media</vocabulary> to record what they're saying. Print media? Sure. Electronic media? Alright? Ghost media? No! Humans can't read that stuff!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In other words, he managed to play the role of the catalyst for those two people.
examples.ja: つまり彼は二人にとって触媒のような役割を果たしたということだ。

meaning_mnemonic: If a <kanji>mediator</kanji> <kanji>touch</kanji>es people the right way, they will become a <vocabulary>catalyst</vocabulary> for change. This could be good or bad change depending on what they stuck their hands in.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Thank you so much for all your hard work in our wedding ceremony matchmaking.
examples.ja: 私どもの結婚式の媒酌の労をおとりいただき、本当にありがとうございました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mediator</kanji> <kanji>serve</kanji>s families and even countries by <vocabulary>matchmaking</vocabulary> for them. They know everyone and everything so to stop family fights and wars, they put two people from each side together to get married and it fixes everything.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Looks like you have to replace the sail soon.
examples.ja: そろそろ帆を替えなくちゃいかんなあ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you <vocabulary>sail</vocabulary> in a ship you can't forget to bring a garden <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ). If you lose your sails or your paddles, you can always use a hoe to paddle your way back. Or if you wreck on an island you can use the hoe to garden so you won't die of starvation! Hoes are very handy!

examples.en: Look, there’s a yacht sailing over there.
examples.ja: ほら、あそこにヨットが帆走しているよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sail</kanji> <kanji>run</kanji>s boats along the sea by <vocabulary>sailing</vocabulary>! You can't run along the water unless the sail is out and catching the wind.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My uncle repairs stringed instruments.
examples.ja: 私の叔父は、弦楽器の修理をしています。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 楽器 means "musical instrument." Well, this one has <kanji>string</kanji>s, making it a <vocabulary>stringed instrument</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Sure, 楽 has two on'yomi readings, but remember: when it's about 音楽 (music), it's read がく. Just bear in mind that がく shortens to がっ here.

examples.en: I want to let the children learn orchestral music.
examples.ja: 子供に管弦楽を習わせたいと思っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 弦楽 means "string music," so add some <kanji>pipe</kanji>s to that, like trumpets and saxophones, and you'll have <vocabulary>orchestral music</vocabulary>. You can't have a whole orchestra with just the string section!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. 楽 has two on'yomi readings, but you know it's がく here because it's about 音楽 (music)!

examples.en: I was deeply moved by the strong feelings in her voice when she sang.
examples.ja: 感慨がこめられた彼女の歌声に感動しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Feeling</kanji>s that make you <kanji>sigh</kanji> out loud are really <vocabulary>strong feelings</vocabulary>. You wouldn't sigh if they didn't move you so much.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I resented your selfish actions.
examples.ja: 君の身勝手な言動に憤慨しているんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>resent</kanji> someone so much that you <kanji>sigh</kanji> with <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary> whenever they're around. Everything they do makes you feel really strong <vocabulary>resentment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are many unreasonable things to feel resentment about at work.
examples.ja: 職場では理不尽なことが多くて憤りを感じています。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>resent</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>resentment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You feel some pretty strong <vocabulary>resentment</vocabulary> toward your roommate because you had to touch their <reading>icky doo</reading>r (いきどお) today and it was covered in what you hope was glue. Or frosting. UHG what an icky door. This is an <vocabulary>outrage</vocabulary>!!!

examples.en: The kindergarteners played along to the music.
examples.ja: 園児たちが音楽にあわせて遊戯をしています。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>play</kanji> and <kanji>play</kanji> all day! What do you play? A <vocabulary>game</vocabulary>! Or a <vocabulary>sport</vocabulary>! Which are technically games!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This musical was originally based off a play.
examples.ja: これは、戯曲を原作としたミュージカルです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>play</kanji> that uses lots of intense, emotional <kanji>music</kanji> is a <vocabulary>drama</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I took a picture of the puppy and the girl playing with it.
examples.ja: 子犬と戯れている少女の写真を撮りました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>play</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to play with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to toy with</vocabulary> someone.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Everyone always seems to yell at you when you start <vocabulary>to toy with</vocabulary> your towel and your <reading>towe</reading>l <reading>mo</reading>ves (たわむ). Just because you don't have anything on under it doesn't mean you can't play with it! Right?!

examples.en: Most students receive support from their parents to live.
examples.ja: ほとんどの学生は、父母の扶助を受けて生活している。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Help</kanji> and <kanji>aid</kanji> someone and you will <vocabulary>help</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>aid</vocabulary> them! Good job, you're a good person.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please let me work in support.
examples.ja: 扶養の範囲内で働かせてください。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Aid</kanji> and <kanji>foster</kanji> someone to show your <vocabulary>support</vocabulary> for them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It's difficult to match the tempo of this tune.
examples.ja: この曲は、拍子を取るのが難しい。

examples.en: I was embarrassed that when I fell my false tooth fell out.
examples.ja: 転んだ拍子に差し歯が抜けてしまい、恥ずかしい思いをした。

examples.en: Well that was anticlimactic.
examples.ja: 拍子抜けしてしまったよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Break down a <kanji>beat</kanji> into all of its <kanji>child</kanji>ren and you’ve got more than just a single beat. You’ve got an assortment of <vocabulary>beat</vocabulary>s, making a <vocabulary>rhythm</vocabulary>, and setting a <vocabulary>tempo</vocabulary>.

Additionally, this can also refer to <vocabulary>the moment</vocabulary> something happens. You’ll usually encounter this in the form of ~した拍子に. Have a look at our context sentences to see this usage in action!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of its kanji. However, 拍 uses its secondary reading, which you haven’t learned yet, so here’s a mnemonic to help you:

You get the <vocabulary>beat</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>rhythm</vocabulary> going in your body. You can't help but sing out loud, "<reading>Heyo</reading> (ひょう), heyo!" Feel that rhythm and sing with me! HEYO HEYO!

examples.en: I felt frozen in the cold air at dawn.
examples.ja: 暁の冷たい空気に、気持ちが張り詰めた。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: This is an eternal masterpiece.
examples.ja: これは不朽の名作です。

meaning_mnemonic: If it does <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>rot</kanji> then it's <vocabulary>immortal</vocabulary>. It will live forever!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That building is pretty decrepit so you shouldn’t go in it.
examples.ja: その建物はかなり老朽しているので、立ち入らない方がいい。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Elderly</kanji> people start to <kanji>decay</kanji> and they get all <vocabulary>decrepit</vocabulary> and gross. Like a corpse. Bleh. Good thing I'll never be <vocabulary>too old</vocabulary>. Ho ho ho!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In the end, I didn’t succeed, never had a girlfriend, and now I’m going to die out.
examples.ja: 結局成功もせず、女もできずに朽ちていくはめになった。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decay</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to decay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to die out</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The entire world would start <vocabulary>to die out</vocabulary> if there were no <reading>coo</reading>kies (く) left! Can you imagine your life without cookies? The trees and animals would all die too. Because they love cookies. Not just us humans.

examples.en: My spine was damaged in the traffic accident and the bottom half of my body became paralyzed.
examples.ja: 交通事故で脊椎を損傷し、下半身不随になったのです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>stature</kanji>'s <kanji>spine</kanji> is really just your <vocabulary>spine</vocabulary>, when you think about it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please put crab shells on this plate.
examples.ja: 蟹の殻はこの皿に入れてください。

examples.en: What do we do after removing the husks from wheat?
examples.ja: 麦の殻を取ったら、その次はどうするの？

examples.en: I watched a video that captured the moment when a seed breaks through its shell and sprouts.
examples.ja: 種の殻を突き破って、芽が出てくる瞬間を捉えたビデオを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word isn't limited to animal shells though! It covers seed shells, or husks, too.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Shell</vocabulary>s are a good defense against <reading>から</reading>て chops. You can't get hurt if you have a nice strong shell to protect you from that からて-chopping weirdo who just showed up out of nowhere.

examples.en: The Japanese archipelago is entering a once-in-a-millennium period of significant tectonic upheaval.
examples.ja: 日本列島は、千年に一度の大地殻変動期に突入しています

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>earth</kanji>'s <kanji>shell</kanji> is called the <vocabulary>earth's crust</vocabulary>. You should have learned that in earth science. And if you didn't, at least you know now!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Kanae has a very graceful personality.
examples.ja: カナエはとってもお淑やかな性格をしている。

examples.en: My mother lacks gentleness.
examples.ja: 母には淑やかさというものが足りない。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you're trying to be <vocabulary>graceful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>polite</vocabulary> you have to keep your secret <reading>shee</reading>p <reading>toe</reading> (しと) under wraps. You're kind of fond of your sheep toe (it's unique after all) but you're careful to hide it when you want to be all modest and gentle and all that.

examples.en: Good evening ladies and gentlemen.
examples.ja: 紳士淑女のみなさん 、こんばんは。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>graceful</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is a proper, fancy <vocabulary>lady</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A regulation was established to prevent the pollution of the lake.
examples.ja: 湖の水質汚濁を防止するために規制が設けられた。

meaning_mnemonic: If the air is <kanji>muddy</kanji> and <kanji>dirty</kanji> it's because there is too much <vocabulary>pollution</vocabulary> in that area. You should wear a mask and be careful of <vocabulary>contamination</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: At the heart of the problem, the company president was vague.
examples.ja: 核心をついた質問に、社長は言葉を濁した。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>muddy</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to make muddy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make cloudy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you want <vocabulary>to make muddy</vocabulary>, meaning make yourself muddy, you should have your <reading>knee</reading>s <reading>go</reading> (にご) first. When you have your knees go first the mud splashes all over you but you don't hurt your hands or your butt doing it.

examples.en: He rescued the things that were gulped down by the muddy stream.
examples.ja: 濁流に飲み込まれそうになったのを、彼が救ってくれたのです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>muddy</kanji> <kanji>stream</kanji> is a <vocabulary>muddy stream</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A disposition was handed down to suspend indictment.
examples.ja: 起訴猶予処分がくだされました。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well you <kanji>wake up</kanji> ready to <kanji>sue</kanji> people when you're told there has been an extension, meaning there was a <vocabulary>suspension of indictment</vocabulary> on your case. What the heck, you woke up ready for this! Now you have to wait to try and sue them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That guy caused other criminal cases during his suspended sentence.
examples.ja: あいつは執行猶予期間中に他の刑事事件を起こしたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" You were supposed to <kanji>carry out</kanji> your sentence and <kanji>go</kanji> to jail, but the judge gave you a 猶予 (extension). In other words, you've received a <vocabulary>suspended sentence</vocabulary>.

執行猶予 means you're guilty, but the judge hits the pause button on your prison time. If you stay out of trouble, the prison time gets dismissed. But if you commit another crime, you must serve both the original and new sentence. Basically, you better hope for a suspended sentence!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Everyone was fascinated by her vibrant voice.
examples.ja: 彼女の瑞々しい歌声が人々を魅了した。

meaning_mnemonic: You give your <kanji>congratulations</kanji> to someone a few times because they seem so <vocabulary>fresh</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vibrant</vocabulary>. You feel like you should because it must be nice to be like that still. Someday it will be gone, so make sure you say it a few times right away.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

examples.en: Where did you get your hands on some sulfuric acid?
examples.ja: どこで硫酸を手に入れたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Mix <kanji>sulfur</kanji> and <kanji>acid</kanji> and you'll get <vocabulary>sulfuric acid</vocabulary>! That's how science works! How simple!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It seems that he keeps stealing for stress reduction.
examples.ja: ストレス解消に窃盗を繰り返していたそうだ。

meaning_mnemonic: You decided to <kanji>steal</kanji>... and then you <kanji>steal</kanji> again a few minutes later! Now you're wanted for <vocabulary>theft</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Stealing</vocabulary> is wrong, you should have known better!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They’re supposed to be tied to a gentlemen’s agreement.
examples.ja: あいつらとは紳士協定を結んでいるはずだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 紳士 means "gentleman?" Well when two men <kanji>determine</kanji> that the best thing to do is <kanji>cooperate</kanji> they form a <vocabulary>gentlemen's agreement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please go buy silk thread at the Nishijin thread store.
examples.ja: 西陣の糸屋で絹糸を買ってきてちょうだい。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>silk</kanji> <kanji>thread</kanji> is <vocabulary>silk thread</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for 絹 and 糸 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who only uses clothes made with <vocabulary>silk thread</vocabulary>? <reading>Ken</reading>'s (けん) <reading>shee</reading>p (し)! Ken's sheep is very particular, and only wears clothes made from silk thread while it's waiting for its wool to grow back.

Note that this word can also be read with the kun'yomi as きぬいと. While けんし tends to sound more technical or formal, often referring to silk thread as a textile material or in industrial contexts, きぬいと is more natural in everyday conversation.

examples.en: Have you ever had sleep paralysis before?
examples.ja: 金縛りにあったことはありますか。

examples.en: I experienced sleep paralysis for the first time in a while last night.
examples.ja: 昨日の夜、久しぶりに金縛りにあったんだよね。

examples.en: I read somewhere that sleep paralysis might be a sign of exhaustion.
examples.ja: 金縛りは疲れてるサインかもってどこかで読んだよ。

examples.en: When you're experiencing sleep paralysis, you can't make a sound, and even if you try to move, you can't budge an inch.
examples.ja: 金縛りにあってる時は、声も出せないし、動こうとしてもピクリともしないんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 縛る means "to bind?" Well, in Japanese being bound by <kanji>gold</kanji> means you're experiencing <vocabulary>sleep paralysis</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>temporary paralysis</vocabulary>. Just imagine that you're waking from a dream where you're bound up in gold thread, and it's stopping you from moving.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 金 and 縛る. Both use the kun'yomi readings, but 金 becomes かな instead of かね. If you can remember that exception, this should be easy!

examples.en: In the Edo period, there was a punishment called death by hanging.
examples.ja: 江戸時代には縛り首という刑罰があった。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 縛る means "to tie?" Well if you tie something around someone's <kanji>neck</kanji> then it's called <vocabulary>hanging</vocabulary>. They'll probably die from it too, so it can also be <vocabulary>death by hanging</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 縛る and 首. Both use the kun'yomi readings, so just change the る to り and it's pretty simple!

examples.en: I sewed it myself, so the stitches are crooked.
examples.ja: 自分で縫ったので縫い目がガタガタなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 縫う means "to sew." Well the only way you can see if a pair of jeans has been sewed with your <kanji>eye</kanji> is if you see a <vocabulary>seam</vocabulary>. If your eyes can't spot the <vocabulary>stitch</vocabulary>es, then it probably wasn't sewed at all. Maybe it was superglued together.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 縫う and 目. Both use the kun'yomi readings so just change the う to い and it's easy! You'll also see this word spelled 縫い目 too. They're exactly the same!

examples.en: I’ll let the artist paint my portrait.
examples.ja: あの画家に私の肖像を描かせてみよう。

meaning_mnemonic: When art <kanji>resemble</kanji>s the <kanji>image</kanji> of a person, it's a <vocabulary>portrait</vocabulary>. And it doesn't just resemble them, it captures their image perfectly. Now that's what I call a portrait.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In the middle of the Edo period, fiefdoms also found financial affairs difficult.
examples.ja: 江戸時代中期には、どこの藩も財政が苦しくなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: We went to visit the daimyo’s tomb.
examples.ja: 藩主の墓に参ってきた。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>master</kanji> of a <kanji>fiefdom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>feudal lord</vocabulary>. We also call them <vocabulary>Daimyo</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please teach me how to record a game.
examples.ja: 棋譜の付け方を教えてください。

meaning_mnemonic: Write down the <kanji>score</kanji>s people get from taking all of their opponent's <kanji>chess piece</kanji>s and you'll be writing down <vocabulary>game records</vocabulary>. This is usually only used for old-fashioned Japanese games like go and shogi. Let's see who has the highest score at the end!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I can play the piano but I can’t read sheet music.
examples.ja: ピアノは弾けますが、楽譜は読めません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>comfort</kanji>ing <kanji>score</kanji> is a <vocabulary>musical score</vocabulary>. Music is really relaxing, and so is reading <vocabulary>sheet music</vocabulary>. You should try it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m sketching my family’s genealogy on this roll of paper.
examples.ja: この巻紙に一族の系譜が描かれています。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>lineage</kanji> and <kanji>genealogy</kanji> make up your <vocabulary>genealogy</vocabulary>, also known as your <vocabulary>family history</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Will you make a chronological record for this author?
examples.ja: この作家の年譜を作ってくれないか。

meaning_mnemonic: Write down the <kanji>year</kanji>s of your <kanji>genealogy</kanji> in order and it makes a <vocabulary>chronological record</vocabulary> of your life. Look back on it when you're old and sigh about the old days.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m looking for a site where I can download music for free.
examples.ja: 譜面を無料でダウンロードできるサイトを探しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>score</kanji> on a <kanji>surface</kanji> is your <vocabulary>sheet music</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>musical score</vocabulary>. 

譜面 often refers more specifically to a music score’s pages. For a more general term for musical score, go with 楽譜.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The president granted amnesty to the turkey.
examples.ja: 大統領は、七面鳥に恩赦を与えた。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Pardon</kanji> someone out of the <kanji>kindness</kanji> in your heart and you'll have granted them <vocabulary>amnesty</vocabulary>. How kind of you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He was granted a special pardon for his crimes.
examples.ja: 彼は特別に罪の赦免が認められた。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>excuse</kanji> and a <kanji>pardon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pardon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>amnesty</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The criminal must be punished without mercy!
examples.ja: 罪人は容赦なく罰せられなくてはならない。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Form</kanji> a <kanji>pardon</kanji> with your mouth and actually <vocabulary>pardon</vocabulary> someone. Show your <vocabulary>forgiveness</vocabulary> with the words "I'm sorry."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We’re looking for a replacement supervisor.
examples.ja: 監督の更迭が求められている。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>renew</kanji> and <kanji>alternate</kanji> certain positions or people, making this a <vocabulary>reshuffle</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>dismissal</vocabulary>.

更迭 generally highlights the dismissal of someone from a position for replacement. You’ll often see this used in political contexts, like the reshuffling of certain ministers or other offices in a cabinet or diet; or just in general for important positions in other fields as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m holding back from evening drinks because of my diet.
examples.ja: ダイエットのために晩酌を控えています。

meaning_mnemonic: At <kanji>night</kanji> you are <kanji>serve</kanji>d an <vocabulary>evening drink</vocabulary>. It's okay to have a strong <vocabulary>drink with dinner</vocabulary> every now and then.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I scooped sake out of the barrel with a ladle.
examples.ja: ヒシャクでタルからお酒を酌んだ。

examples.en: Why don't you take his opinion into consideration a little?
examples.ja: ちょっとはあいつの意見も酌んでやったらどう？

examples.en: Please hurry up and get the sake in this cup.
examples.ja: 急いでこのおちょこにお酒を酌んできてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>serve</kanji>, and the verb version is <vocabulary>to scoop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to serve</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>to take into consideration</vocabulary> someone else's feelings or opinions. Kind of like you're scooping up the person's feelings and considering them!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What do you decide <vocabulary>to scoop</vocabulary> out for your guests? <reading>Coo</reading>kies (く)! But not just any cookies. Cookie smoothies! They're delicious and you won't serve anyone anything else. They must drink your delicious cookie drinks.

examples.en: Please take one tablet of this medicine once every day.
examples.ja: この薬を必ず一日一錠飲んで下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I was mistaken for a criminal and handcuffed.
examples.ja: 犯人と間違われて手錠を掛けられたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>lock</kanji> this criminal's <kanji>hand</kanji>s up so he won't go punching anymore grandpas. You need some <vocabulary>handcuffs</vocabulary> to make sure he doesn't go around being a criminal anymore. Then you can lock him up good.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. You know them both, so this shouldn't be too hard to remember!

examples.en: I can’t swallow pills, so I smash and drink them.
examples.ja: 錠剤を飲み込むことができないので、砕いて飲んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: You take a <kanji>dose</kanji> of medicine but it gets <kanji>lock</kanji>ed in your throat because it's the kind of <vocabulary>pill</vocabulary> you chew, not swallow! You need to pay attention to which one is which or it won't help at all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please teach me everything about the introduction of jury trials in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本で陪審裁判が導入された経緯を教えてください。

meaning_mnemonic: Who is going to <kanji>accompany</kanji> the <kanji>judge</kanji> in deciding the results of the trial? The <vocabulary>jury</vocabulary>! They're the only other people besides the judge who can decide someone's fate in court.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Well, I’m fickle.
examples.ja: 私って、飽きっぽいのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>bored</kanji> all the time it makes you tired and the <vocabulary>weariness</vocabulary> you feel will show on your face.
reading_mnemonic: Remember how you learned 飽きる? Well just take of the る and it's the same thing. If you can remember that, you'll know this no problem!

examples.en: This is a stubbornly self-centered opinion.
examples.ja: 飽くまでも、これは個人的な見解です。

meaning_mnemonic: I'm so <kanji>bored</kanji>. On top of my boredom is くまでも. If you took this separately, it would mean "even as a bear." So it's like you're saying I'm so <kanji>bored</kanji>, even if I was a bear. If you're so bored that you'd be bored even as a bear, you're going to be bored <vocabulary>to the last</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to the end</vocabulary>. Nothing will please you, you bored bear person.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 飽きる so you should be able to read this one too!

examples.en: The chick I raised became a chicken.
examples.ja: 育てたひよこが鶏になりました。

examples.en: My neighbor's chickens wake me up every morning.
examples.ja: 隣の家で飼っている鶏が毎朝起こしてくれるんですよ。

examples.en: Am I right about this chicken being a rooster?
examples.ja: この鶏は雄鶏で合ってる？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

A <vocabulary>chicken</vocabulary> is a <reading>庭</reading> (garden) <reading>鳥</reading> (bird) (にわとり). It's a bird that you keep in your garden, after all!

examples.en: I try to make sure I eat as much white meat from chicken as I can.
examples.ja: できるだけ鶏肉のささみを食べるようにしています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Chicken</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji> is <vocabulary>chicken meat</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses a kun'yomi reading for 鶏 that you haven't learned yet (とり), plus the usual on'yomi for 肉. Sounds tricky, but remember how 鳥 is とり? Chicken meat is basically just bird meat, so think of it like that when you're trying to remember this reading!

examples.en: Chicken eggs are the only source of protein in Japan that is self sufficient.
examples.ja: 鶏卵は日本が自給自足できる唯一の蛋白源です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>chicken</kanji> <kanji>egg</kanji> is a <vocabulary>chicken egg</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 卵 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who loves <vocabulary>chicken eggs</vocabulary>? <reading>Ran</reading>dy (らん) Savage! Especially when he eats them with slim jims. Mmm eggs and slim jims. You should give it a try.

examples.en: I realized how difficult managing poultry raising is.
examples.ja: 養鶏経営の難しさを痛感しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Foster</kanji> a bunch of <kanji>chicken</kanji>s and start <vocabulary>chicken farming</vocabulary>! They will be your best friends! Your only friends.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My father's various experiences led to his resignation.
examples.ja: 父は、様々な経験の後に諦観に至った。

examples.en: Motivation became resignation before long.
examples.ja: やる気はやがて、諦観となった。

examples.en: You are too young to be resigned.
examples.ja: 君は諦観するにはまだ若い。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>give up</kanji> and just try to enjoy the <kanji>view</kanji>, that's <vocabulary>resignation</vocabulary>. You know things aren't going well, and you know you can't do anything about it now, so you resign yourself to what's to come.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 諦, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In <vocabulary>resignation</vocabulary>, you throw all of your <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots onto the ground. Look at the tater tots at your feet. Now they're lying scattered there, a symbol of your feelings of resignation.

examples.en: It's wasteful to throw away food, isn't it?
examples.ja: 食べ物を捨てるのは勿体ない事ですよね。

examples.en: It's such a waste that you went to Japan but never got to see a taiko performance.
examples.ja: 折角日本に行ったのに、太鼓の演奏を見ることができないなんて勿体ないですよね。

examples.en: Ayano-chan, you're too good for Ryohei!
examples.ja: 綾乃ちゃんは、亮平には勿体ないよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>must not</kanji> use your <kanji>body</kanji> for anything <vocabulary>wasteful</vocabulary>, because that would be <vocabulary>a waste</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>too good</vocabulary> for that!

This word is used in all kinds of situations where there's a feeling that something is going to waste, including food, money, time, talent, and opportunities. You can also use it to say that someone is too good for a job, or even for another person. While it's usually written in kana, you'll see it in kanji too.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji, except that もち becomes もっ.

examples.en: Entertainment in the Edo period was joruri and kabuki.
examples.ja: 江戸時代の娯楽は、浄瑠璃や歌舞伎だった。

examples.en: I got a ticket for a ningyo joruri performance.
examples.ja: 人形浄瑠璃のチケットをもらいました。

examples.en: This time, we interviewed a creator of joruri puppets.
examples.ja: 今回は、浄瑠璃人形の作り手にインタビューをしました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>cleanse</kanji> a <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji> rock until it goes <kanji>glassy</kanji>, you can use it in a <vocabulary>joruri</vocabulary> performance. In case you haven't heard of joruri, it's traditional Japanese chanted storytelling, sort of like a <vocabulary>ballad</vocabulary>, that's accompanied by shamisen music, and often puppets.
reading_mnemonic: You learned all these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Riko showed up wearing a bright blue dress at the place she was meeting Ryoichiro.
examples.ja: 莉子は、瑠璃色のワンピースを着て諒一郎との待ち合わせ場所に現れた。

examples.en: Bright blue and spherical in shape, the higotai is a very pretty flower.
examples.ja: ヒゴタイは、瑠璃色で丸い形をした、とても可愛い花です。

examples.en: Suddenly, a beautiful bright blue insect that looked like a jewel caught my eye.
examples.ja: ふと、瑠璃色の美しい宝石のような虫が目にとまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
What is <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji> <kanji>glassy</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>bright blue</vocabulary>. If you've never seen the rock lapis lazuli, look it up and you'll see why this means bright blue!

This word is generally used in literature.
reading_mnemonic: You learned all three of these readings when you learned the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Sugahara's a cool surname, isn't it?
examples.ja: 菅原っていう苗字、なんかかっこよくね？

examples.en: Oh, Sugawara-san, do you have a cold?
examples.ja: あれ、菅原さん、風邪ですか？

examples.en: At Sugawara Shoe Store, I bought a pair of stylish leather shoes.
examples.ja: 菅原靴店で、オシャレな革靴を買った。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Sedge</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is both <vocabulary>Sugahara</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>Sugawara</vocabulary>, the Japanese family names. Sedgefield is a family name (and a place-name) in English too, so that might help you with this one!

This is a very old surname, said to have originated with Nara period scholar Hanishi-no-sukune (土師宿禰) who changed his name to Sugawara-no-furuhito (菅原古人). Historically, the name has been associated with scholars and writers, including prominent Heian period statesman, scholar, and poet Sugawara-no-michizane (菅原道真) and noblewoman, writer, and poet Sugawara-no-takasue-no-musume (菅原孝標女), also known more simply as Lady Sarashina in the English speaking world.
reading_mnemonic:
The only reading you haven't learned for this name is the irregular わら reading for 原, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Sugawara</vocabulary>-san went to <reading>war a</reading> (わら) long time ago, but these days he enjoys a quiet life tending to his <kanji>sedge</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji>s.

examples.en: May I pour you some sake?
examples.ja: お酌をさせていただいてもよろしいですか。

examples.en: Manager, it is discriminatory to have female employees fill others' glasses just because they are female.
examples.ja: 部長、女性社員だからという理由で酌をさせるのは差別ですよ。

examples.en: What, you're gonna turn down me pouring you alcohol?!
examples.ja: 何だ、お前、俺の酌を断るのか！？

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>serve</kanji> someone, you're <vocabulary>pouring alcohol</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pouring sake</vocabulary> for them. You're <vocabulary>filling someone's glass</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji. Cheers!

examples.en: In Japanese trials there is something called "making allowances for extenuating circumstances".
examples.ja: 日本の裁判には「情状酌量」とよばれるものがあります。

examples.en: I don't think there's scope to make allowances for extenuating circumstances.
examples.ja: 情状酌量の余地はないと思います。

examples.en: Concluding that the defendant's circumstances should be taken into consideration, the judge commuted the sentence.
examples.ja: 被告人には酌量すべき情状があると判断し、裁判官は刑を減軽した。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>serve</kanji> someone a certain <kanji>quantity</kanji> of understanding, you're <vocabulary>making allowances</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>taking into consideration</vocabulary> all extenuating circumstances.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
